photos.description: TBD
TBD
Judging from the fancy clothes and shoes it was an important occasion, maybe graduation?
Ken Culver with 'the old Merc' outboard jigging herring for summer money.

Ken Culver's Mercury 'Hurricane 10'. 'A screamer. Essentially a racing engine.' Ken built the hydroplane in his grandmother's basement while in high school from plans he sent away for from Popular Mechanics. He had to remove the door to get it out. This 10 hp would run circles around the Evinrude 15 and 20 hp of the day by winding up to a much higher RPM which worked fine on a light boat, but it was not worth beans for towing a surfboard or skier - no low end torque. No gear shift - so you had to plan ahead before starting it as you would lunge ahead once it fired. (Ken)

Ken Culver and girlfriend 'Brenda' from Seattle's Capitol Hill area with herring catch. In the background is sand and gravel (most likely used by Carroll Culver to build his fence posts or floor tiles). (Ken)

The 'big float' after launch, waiting for tide to come in and float it into position. Launching and retrieving the floats was a huge job, involving jacks, pulleys, planks, and rollers (the round cores of logs that had been peeled by a plywood mill in Bellingham.) The process took several days in and out, and had to be coordinated with large tides. Weather was critical so floats were generally not put in the water until close to Memorial Day and always taken out by September 15 as my father worried about the 1st big fall storm coming any time after. The large box with what appear to be windows is the floating live box that would be anchored in the bay. The large box laying on its side on top of the float was the small live box that would be placed under a trap door in the float after launch to store live herring caught by jigging with barbless single hooks. (Ken)
Ken Culver's Seattle girlfriend Brenda with herring catch.

The 'Living Room' at the Point Lawrence Lodge. By the time this photo was taken the dining room was closed. Two of the dining room tables were pushed together to support a ping pong table. Both Ken and Bruce got to be pretty good ping pong players. The corner of OH Culver's oak desk is just visible in the far right of the picture. All 3 Culver children learned to roller skate, ride trikes, and even bicycles in this large room. The room could be heated with the wood fired heater visible against the far wall, but it was rarely used except for special occasions. (Ken)
photos.notes: Note the large portrait on the back wall. This hung in Carrol Culver's Shorecrest home and now hangs in Ken Culver's basement shop in Bellingham, WA.

photos.description: Rigging up fishing pole. Motor barrel to right (for testing or flushing outboard motors).

Ken Culver with his red and blue 'sea sled'. This was a plywood boat that ended up self-destructing while underway when the bottom sheet of plywood pulled off the frames after a high-speed run through the bay. A man that Vic Hughes knew built the boat in Bellingham and brought it to the Island and ended up giving it to Ken. I put a 20 hp Mercury on it. It could barely turn when underway, but as long as you went straight it flew! A terrible design, which after my spectacular crash (documented elsewhere) ended up in a large beach fire. (Ken)

Cessna seaplane from Bergsma's flying service in Bellingham taking off into the breeze from Pt. Lawrence Lodge. Les Bergsma's Flying Service from Bellingham. This little plane was often busy on weekends shuttling people to and from their summer cabins or fishing destinations. A 15 minute flight from Lake Whatcom in Bellingham to Pt Lawrence or Doe Bay meant that people like Helge Johanson, Dr. Ralph Sharninghouse, Victor Hughes, Ken Ireland and Max Hanson could enjoy Friday evening at their cabins and fly home just before dusk on Sunday evening. (Ken)

Carl Atwood was a guest at the lodge. He later wrote a book 'The Last Two Weeks In August'. He was from Yakima. The Culvers would stay with the Atwoods in the off-season. He and Ken Culver ended up in neighboring fraternity houses at the University of Washington. Both started in engineeringâ€”Carl finished in engineering - Ken graduated from the business school.
Portrait of Georges Dehousse on the beach. He was a Belgian exchange student who stayed with the Culver family during Ken's senior year at Garfield High School.
Georges Dehousse on the beach. He was a Belgian exchange student who stayed with the Culver family.
Portrait of Georges Dehousse on the beach. He was a Belgian exchange student who stayed with the Culver family.

Graduation photo of Georges Dehousse (a Belgian exchange student who stayed with the Culver family). Georges graduated with Ken from Garfield High School - Seattle and spent part of the summer at Orcas before returning to his home town of Liege in Belgium.

Spring 1958 taken from the porch of the Lodge. I believe the floats were not put in the water that year, as Carroll had decided to shut down the resort business. He still allowed old customers to come and rent the cabins, but they had to do their own laundry, and clean up when leaving. Carroll was preoccupied with beginning to build his retirement home at Doe Bay. (Ken)

The four Culver sisters were married in two double weddings. Mary and her sister Florian were married to G. Mason Hall and Helge Johansen on July 16, 1929 at their parents' house on Ellis Street in Bellingham. (David Hall)

photos.people: Mabel Culver, George Hall, Otis Henry (O.H.) Culver
photos.description: O.H. and Mabel Culver hold their grandson George Hall who would grow up to be a prominent medical doctor.
